title: Ford circle
summary: In mathematics, a Ford circle is a circle in the Euclidean plane, in a family of circles that are all tangent to the x {\displaystyle x} -axis at rational points. For each rational number p / q {\displaystyle p/q} , expressed in lowest terms, there is a Ford circle whose center is at the point ( p / q , 1 / ( 2 q 2 ) ) {\displaystyle (p/q,1/(2q^{2}))} and whose radius is 1 / ( 2 q 2 ) {\displaystyle 1/(2q^{2})} . It is tangent to the x {\displaystyle x} -axis at its bottom point, ( p / q , 0 ) {\displaystyle (p/q,0)} .
